text: when it comes to the political argument
over the economy two words crop up again
and again debt and deficit they may
sound similar but don't be confused they
are entirely different think of it this
way the national debt is like your
mortgage loan for the car money you've
borrowed from your parents credit cards
all rolled into one
it's everything you own sound government
terms debt is made up of all the bills
the nation has accumulated over
centuries including for Wars and
financial emergencies like the banking
crash and on which we as taxpayers have
to pay interest not surprisingly this is
a fairly huge figure at present more
than one and a half trillion pounds or
sixty four thousand pounds for every
household the deficit is more like when
you slip into the red it's how much
you've overspent on your weekly pay or
monthly salary it's the nation's annual
overdraft which last year was 90 billion
pounds the torah's say they've half the
deficit over this Parliament and want to
get rid of it by 2018 the Lib Dems agree
but say they'd rely more on tax rises
while labour back a more gradual pace
eradicating the deficit by 2020 but the
reason all three parties are desperate
and the deficit is this a deficit means
more borrowing which means more debt
which means bigger interest bills which
means less money to spend on things like
schools and hospitals
